div1.p: The Commission of Fine Arts and the Chairman of the House Committee on the Library disapprove of the monument to Reed, Carroll, Lazear, and Agramonte. They suggest a memorial fountain instead. Included is a copy of Senate Bill #6067. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from the Secretary of War to the President of the Senate, June 29, 1916
div1.opener:

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
2408973 A.G.O.
101498 Engrs.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
wsh
WASHINGTON,
CK
MMB
June 29, 1916.
The President of the Senate,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I beg to submit the following report on Senate Bill 6067, 64th Congress,
1st Session, providing for the erection on the public grounds in this city of
a monument to the memory of Major Walter Reed, Surgeons James Carroll, Jesse
W. Lazear and Aristides Agramonte.

The Commission of Fine Arts as well as the Chairman of the House Committee
on the Library have expressed strong disapproval of the erection of any addition-
al portrait statues in the public grounds of this city. If, therefore, a monu-
ment is to be erected to those named in the bill, it would be better that it
should take the form of a memorial fountain of which there are but two in Wash-
ington. Such a memorial, if well designed, should be an acceptable addition to
the public grounds of the city.

There is now in the suburbs of this city a hospital named after Major
Walter Reed, one of those mentioned in the bill. It is suggested that the
grounds of that institution might afford a more appropriate site for the pro-
posed monument.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, Secretary of War. One inclosure, viz:
Copy of S. 6067, 64:1.

War Department, A. G. O., June 5, 1916.
To the Surgeon General of
the Army.

For preparation of a report on the accompanying bill, for transmis-
sion to Congress. That report will be transmitted to this office at the
earliest practicable date.
By order of the Secretary of War:

H.P. McCain
The Adjutant General.

157365
2d Indt.
HHW
War Dept., S.G.O., June 6, 1916. - To The Adjutant General.

1. The services rendered and sacrifices made by Doctors Reed,
Carroll, Lazear and Agramonte in demonstrating the mode of trans-
mission of yellow fever have been and will be of inestimable value
to mankind, and a monument to commemmorate them in the capital city
of the United States would be most appropriate. I recommend there-
fore that a favorable report by made upon S. 6067 herewith.

W. C. Gorgas.
Surgeon General.
Army
